example: Countless other words such as HONOUR, JUSTICE, MORALITY, INTERNATIONALISM, DEMOCRACY, SCIENCE, and RELIGION had simply ceased to exist.

name: SCIENCE
trans: n. 科学；学科
example: Countless other words such as HONOUR, JUSTICE, MORALITY, INTERNATIONALISM, DEMOCRACY, SCIENCE, and RELIGION had simply ceased to exist.

name: RELIGION
trans: n. 宗教，信仰
example: Countless other words such as HONOUR, JUSTICE, MORALITY, INTERNATIONALISM, DEMOCRACY, SCIENCE, and RELIGION had simply ceased to exist.

name: blanket
trans: n. 毯子(可数)；厚厚一层(可数)vt. 铺上一层
example: A few blanket words covered them, and, in covering them, abolished them.

name: objectivity
trans: n. 客观；客观性
example: All words grouping themselves round the concepts of liberty and equality, for instance, were contained in the single word CRIMETHINK, while all words grouping themselves round the concepts of objectivity and rationalism were contained in the single word OLDTHINK.

name: rationalism
example: All words grouping themselves round the concepts of liberty and equality, for instance, were contained in the single word CRIMETHINK, while all words grouping themselves round the concepts of objectivity and rationalism were contained in the single word OLDTHINK.

name: Greater
trans: than,大于
example: Greater precision would have been dangerous.

name: Hebrew
example: What was required in a Party member was an outlook similar to that of the ancient Hebrew who knew, without knowing much else, that all nations other than his own worshipped 'false gods'.

name: worshipped
trans: n. 礼拜，礼拜仪式；崇拜v. 崇拜，敬仰；做礼拜
example: What was required in a Party member was an outlook similar to that of the ancient Hebrew who knew, without knowing much else, that all nations other than his own worshipped 'false gods'.

name: gods
trans: n. 上帝(小写god泛指所有的“神，神像”)
example: What was required in a Party member was an outlook similar to that of the ancient Hebrew who knew, without knowing much else, that all nations other than his own worshipped 'false gods'.

name: Baal
example: He did not need to know that these gods were called Baal, Osiris, Moloch, Ashtaroth, and the like: probably the less he knew about them the better for his orthodoxy.

name: Osiris
example: He did not need to know that these gods were called Baal, Osiris, Moloch, Ashtaroth, and the like: probably the less he knew about them the better for his orthodoxy.

name: Moloch
example: He did not need to know that these gods were called Baal, Osiris, Moloch, Ashtaroth, and the like: probably the less he knew about them the better for his orthodoxy.

name: Ashtaroth
example: He did not need to know that these gods were called Baal, Osiris, Moloch, Ashtaroth, and the like: probably the less he knew about them the better for his orthodoxy.

name: Jehovah
example: He knew Jehovah and the commandments of Jehovah: he knew, therefore, that all gods with other names or other attributes were false gods.

name: commandments
trans: n.称赞
example: He knew Jehovah and the commandments of Jehovah: he knew, therefore, that all gods with other names or other attributes were false gods.

name: attributes
trans: vt. 归因于;n. 属性;象征;标志
example: He knew Jehovah and the commandments of Jehovah: he knew, therefore, that all gods with other names or other attributes were false gods.

name: constituted
trans: vt. 组成，构成，形成；设立，建立，任命
example: In somewhat the same way, the party member knew what constituted right conduct, and in exceedingly vague, generalized terms he knew what kinds of departure from it were possible.

name: exceedingly
trans: ad. 极端地，非常
example: In somewhat the same way, the party member knew what constituted right conduct, and in exceedingly vague, generalized terms he knew what kinds of departure from it were possible.

name: generalized
trans: adj.广泛的,普遍的,非具体的,整体的v.概括，归纳,推论(generalize的过去式和过去分词),推广，普及
example: In somewhat the same way, the party member knew what constituted right conduct, and in exceedingly vague, generalized terms he knew what kinds of departure from it were possible.

name: departure
trans: n. 离开，起程
example: In somewhat the same way, the party member knew what constituted right conduct, and in exceedingly vague, generalized terms he knew what kinds of departure from it were possible.

name: SEXCRIME
example: His sexual life, for example, was entirely regulated by the two Newspeak words SEXCRIME (sexual immorality) and GOODSEX (chastity).

name: immorality
trans: n. 道德,美德;伦理体系
example: His sexual life, for example, was entirely regulated by the two Newspeak words SEXCRIME (sexual immorality) and GOODSEX (chastity).

name: GOODSEX
example: His sexual life, for example, was entirely regulated by the two Newspeak words SEXCRIME (sexual immorality) and GOODSEX (chastity).

name: misdeeds
trans: n.罪行, 犯罪。
example: SEXCRIME covered all sexual misdeeds whatever.

name: adultery
trans: 通奸，通奸行为
example: It covered fornication, adultery, homosexuality, and other perversions, and, in addition, normal intercourse practised for its own sake.

name: perversions
trans: n.歪曲，曲解,变坏,医性欲倒错,心性变态
example: It covered fornication, adultery, homosexuality, and other perversions, and, in addition, normal intercourse practised for its own sake.

name: enumerate
trans: v.列举
example: There was no need to enumerate them separately, since they were all equally culpable, and, in principle, all punishable by death.

name: culpable
trans: adj. 有罪的；该责备的；不周到的；应受处罚的
example: There was no need to enumerate them separately, since they were all equally culpable, and, in principle, all punishable by death.

name: aberrations
trans: anomaly
example: In the C vocabulary, which consisted of scientific and technical words, it might be necessary to give specialized names to certain sexual aberrations, but the ordinary citizen had no need of them.

name: begetting
trans: vt. 产生；招致；引起；当……的父亲
example: He knew what was meant by GOODSEX--that is to say, normal intercourse between man and wife, for the sole purpose of begetting children, and without physical pleasure on the part of the woman: all else was SEXCRIME.

name: perception
trans: n.感觉；概念；理解力
example: In Newspeak it was seldom possible to follow a heretical thought further than the perception that it WAS heretical: beyond that point the necessary words were nonexistent.

name: nonexistent
trans: adj.不存在的
example: In Newspeak it was seldom possible to follow a heretical thought further than the perception that it WAS heretical: beyond that point the necessary words were nonexistent.

name: ideologically
trans: adv.思想体系上，意识形态上
example: No word in the B vocabulary was ideologically neutral.

name: euphemisms
trans: 婉言，委婉的说法
example: A great many were euphemisms.

name: JOYCAMP
example: Such words, for instance, as JOYCAMP (forced-labour camp) or MINIPAX (Ministry of Peace, i.

name: exact
trans: a. 确切的，正确的，精确的
example: Ministry of War) meant almost the exact opposite of what they appeared to mean.

name: displayed
trans: vt./n. 展览,陈列
example: Some words, on the other hand, displayed a frank and contemptuous understanding of the real nature of Oceanic society.

name: contemptuous
trans: adj.轻视的
example: Some words, on the other hand, displayed a frank and contemptuous understanding of the real nature of Oceanic society.

name: PROLEFEED
example: An example was PROLEFEED, meaning the rubbishy entertainment and spurious news which the Party handed out to the masses.

name: Other
trans: a. 另外的，其他的n./pron. 另一个人(或事)
example: Other words, again, were ambivalent, having the connotation 'good' when applied to the Party and 'bad' when applied to its enemies.

name: ambivalent
trans: adj.矛盾的, 好恶相克的。
example: Other words, again, were ambivalent, having the connotation 'good' when applied to the Party and 'bad' when applied to its enemies.

name: connotation
trans: n. 内涵；含蓄；暗示，隐含意义；储蓄的东西 形容词: connotative
example: Other words, again, were ambivalent, having the connotation 'good' when applied to the Party and 'bad' when applied to its enemies.

name: derived
trans: vt. 取得,得到;追溯…的起源(或来由); vi. (from) 起源,衍生
example: But in addition there were great numbers of words which at first sight appeared to be mere abbreviations and which derived their ideological colour not from their meaning, but from their structure.

name: contrived
trans: 不自然的，刻意的
example: So far as it could be contrived, everything that had or might have political significance of any kind was fitted into the B vocabulary.

name: institution
trans: n. 公共机构；协会；学校；研究所；制度；惯例
example: The name of every organization, or body of people, or doctrine, or country, or institution, or public building, was invariably cut down into the familiar shape; that is, a single easily pronounced word with the smallest number of syllables that would preserve the original derivation.

name: pronounced
trans: adj. 明显的;显著的
example: The name of every organization, or body of people, or doctrine, or country, or institution, or public building, was invariably cut down into the familiar shape; that is, a single easily pronounced word with the smallest number of syllables that would preserve the original derivation.

name: RECDEP
example: In the Ministry of Truth, for example, the Records Department, in which Winston Smith worked, was called RECDEP, the Fiction Department was called FICDEP, the Teleprogrammes Department was called TELEDEP, and so on.

name: FICDEP
example: In the Ministry of Truth, for example, the Records Department, in which Winston Smith worked, was called RECDEP, the Fiction Department was called FICDEP, the Teleprogrammes Department was called TELEDEP, and so on.

name: Teleprogrammes
example: In the Ministry of Truth, for example, the Records Department, in which Winston Smith worked, was called RECDEP, the Fiction Department was called FICDEP, the Teleprogrammes Department was called TELEDEP, and so on.

name: TELEDEP
example: In the Ministry of Truth, for example, the Records Department, in which Winston Smith worked, was called RECDEP, the Fiction Department was called FICDEP, the Teleprogrammes Department was called TELEDEP, and so on.

name: solely
trans: ad.单独地，唯一地
example: This was not done solely with the object of saving time.

name: telescoped
trans: n. 望远镜v. 缩短，压缩
example: Even in the early decades of the twentieth century, telescoped words and phrases had been one of the characteristic features of political language; and it had been noticed that the tendency to use abbreviations of this kind was most marked in totalitarian countries and totalitarian organizations.

name: Examples
trans: n. 例子，实例；模范，榜样
example: Examples were such words as NAZI, GESTAPO, COMINTERN, INPRECORR, AGITPROP.

name: NAZI
example: Examples were such words as NAZI, GESTAPO, COMINTERN, INPRECORR, AGITPROP.

name: GESTAPO
example: Examples were such words as NAZI, GESTAPO, COMINTERN, INPRECORR, AGITPROP.

name: COMINTERN
example: Examples were such words as NAZI, GESTAPO, COMINTERN, INPRECORR, AGITPROP.

name: INPRECORR
example: Examples were such words as NAZI, GESTAPO, COMINTERN, INPRECORR, AGITPROP.

name: AGITPROP
example: Examples were such words as NAZI, GESTAPO, COMINTERN, INPRECORR, AGITPROP.

name: adopted
trans: adj.被收养的，被采用的v.采用( adopt的过去式和过去分词 ),收养,正式接受,吸收（外来词语）
example: In the beginning the practice had been adopted as it were instinctively, but in Newspeak it was used with a conscious purpose.

name: thus
trans: ad. 如此；像这样；于是；因此
example: It was perceived that in thus abbreviating a name one narrowed and subtly altered its meaning, by cutting out most of the associations that would otherwise cling to it.

name: abbreviating
trans: v.缩写, 缩短, 简化, 简写成, 缩写为。
example: It was perceived that in thus abbreviating a name one narrowed and subtly altered its meaning, by cutting out most of the associations that would otherwise cling to it.

name: associations
trans: 协会
example: It was perceived that in thus abbreviating a name one narrowed and subtly altered its meaning, by cutting out most of the associations that would otherwise cling to it.

name: COMMUNIST
trans: n.共产党员
example: The words COMMUNIST INTERNATIONAL, for instance, call up a composite picture of universal human brotherhood, red flags, barricades, Karl Marx, and the Paris Commune.

name: INTERNATIONAL
trans: a. 国际的，世界(性)的，跨国的
example: The words COMMUNIST INTERNATIONAL, for instance, call up a composite picture of universal human brotherhood, red flags, barricades, Karl Marx, and the Paris Commune.

name: Karl
example: The words COMMUNIST INTERNATIONAL, for instance, call up a composite picture of universal human brotherhood, red flags, barricades, Karl Marx, and the Paris Commune.

name: Marx
example: The words COMMUNIST INTERNATIONAL, for instance, call up a composite picture of universal human brotherhood, red flags, barricades, Karl Marx, and the Paris Commune.

name: Commune
trans: n.公社
example: The words COMMUNIST INTERNATIONAL, for instance, call up a composite picture of universal human brotherhood, red flags, barricades, Karl Marx, and the Paris Commune.

name: suggests
trans: v. 建议，提出；使联想，使想起…；暗示
example: The word COMINTERN, on the other hand, suggests merely a tightly-knit organization and a well-defined body of doctrine.

name: knit
trans: v. 编织;紧密结合
example: The word COMINTERN, on the other hand, suggests merely a tightly-knit organization and a well-defined body of doctrine.

name: refers
trans: v. 参考，查询；提到，引用，涉及；提交，上呈
example: It refers to something almost as easily recognized, and as limited in purpose, as a chair or a table.

name: linger
trans: vi. 逗留,徘徊;动作迟缓;苟延残喘
example: COMINTERN is a word that can be uttered almost without taking thought, whereas COMMUNIST INTERNATIONAL is a phrase over which one is obliged to linger at least momentarily.

name: MINISTRY
trans: n. (政府的)部；牧师
example: In the same way, the associations called up by a word like MINITRUE are fewer and more controllable than those called up by MINISTRY OF TRUTH.

name: TRUTH
trans: n. 真实，真相；真实性；真理
example: In the same way, the associations called up by a word like MINITRUE are fewer and more controllable than those called up by MINISTRY OF TRUTH.

name: accounted
trans: n. 账目;账户;计算;vt./vi. 说明
example: This accounted not only for the habit of abbreviating whenever possible, but also for the almost exaggerated care that was taken to make every word easily pronounceable.

name: outweighed
trans: v.在重量(或价值等)上超过。
example: In Newspeak, euphony outweighed every consideration other than exactitude of meaning.

name: consideration
trans: n. 需要考虑的事，理由；考虑，思考；体谅，照顾
example: In Newspeak, euphony outweighed every consideration other than exactitude of meaning.

name: exactitude
trans: meticulousness
example: In Newspeak, euphony outweighed every consideration other than exactitude of meaning.

name: Regularity
trans: n.规则性；整齐
example: Regularity of grammar was always sacrificed to it when it seemed necessary.

name: echoes
trans: n./v. 反响,回声
example: And rightly so, since what was required, above all for political purposes, was short clipped words of unmistakable meaning which could be uttered rapidly and which roused the minimum of echoes in the speaker's mind.

name: gained
trans: v. 获得；增加；表等走快n. 增进，增加；收益
example: The words of the B vocabulary even gained in force from the fact that nearly all of them were very much alike.

name: stress
trans: n. 压力,重压 vt. 着重,强调重点,重视
example: Almost invariably these words--GOODTHINK, MINIPAX, PROLEFEED, SEXCRIME, JOYCAMP, INGSOC, BELLYFEEL, THINKPOL, and countless others--were words of two or three syllables, with the stress distributed equally between the first syllable and the last.

name: monotonous
trans: a. 单调的,无变化的
example: The use of them encouraged a gabbling style of speech, at once staccato and monotonous.

name: aimed
trans: n. 目的；瞄准vi. (at)目的在于vt. 把…瞄准
example: And this was exactly what was aimed at.

name: intention
trans: n. 意图，意向，目的
example: The intention was to make speech, and especially speech on any subject not ideologically neutral, as nearly as possible independent of consciousness.

name: ethical
trans: n. 处方药
adj. 伦理的；道德的；凭处方出售的
example: For the purposes of everyday life it was no doubt necessary, or sometimes necessary, to reflect before speaking, but a Party member called upon to make a political or ethical judgement should be able to spray forth the correct opinions as automatically as a machine gun spraying forth bullets.

name: judgement
trans: n.意见；审判；判断
example: For the purposes of everyday life it was no doubt necessary, or sometimes necessary, to reflect before speaking, but a Party member called upon to make a political or ethical judgement should be able to spray forth the correct opinions as automatically as a machine gun spraying forth bullets.

name: spray
trans: vt./n. 水花;飞沫;喷射
example: For the purposes of everyday life it was no doubt necessary, or sometimes necessary, to reflect before speaking, but a Party member called upon to make a political or ethical judgement should be able to spray forth the correct opinions as automatically as a machine gun spraying forth bullets.

name: spraying
trans: n.喷雾v.喷( spray的现在分词 ),向…扫射（或抛洒），往…上撒,尤指雄猫撒尿（以示领地占有）
example: For the purposes of everyday life it was no doubt necessary, or sometimes necessary, to reflect before speaking, but a Party member called upon to make a political or ethical judgement should be able to spray forth the correct opinions as automatically as a machine gun spraying forth bullets.

name: foolproof
trans: n. 极简单；安全自锁装置
adj. 十分简单的；十分安全的；不会错的
example: His training fitted him to do this, the language gave him an almost foolproof instrument, and the texture of the words, with their harsh sound and a certain wilful ugliness which was in accord with the spirit of Ingsoc, assisted the process still further.

name: choose
trans: v. 选择，挑选；甘愿
example: So did the fact of having very few words to choose from.

name: Relative
trans: a. 相对的，比较的，有关系的n. 亲戚，关系词
example: Relative to our own, the Newspeak vocabulary was tiny, and new ways of reducing it were constantly being devised.

name: reducing
trans: v. 减少，缩小；简化，还原
example: Relative to our own, the Newspeak vocabulary was tiny, and new ways of reducing it were constantly being devised.

name: differed
trans: v. (from)与…不同；(with)与…意见不同
example: Newspeak, indeed, differed from most all other languages in that its vocabulary grew smaller instead of larger every year.

name: gain
trans: v. 获得；增加；表等走快n. 增进，增加；收益
example: Each reduction was a gain, since the smaller the area of choice, the smaller the temptation to take thought.

name: articulate
trans: adj.有关节的, 发音清晰的。vt.用关节连接, 接合, 清晰明白地说。
example: Ultimately it was hoped to make articulate speech issue from the larynx without involving the higher brain centres at all.

name: frankly
trans: adv.坦率地
example: This aim was frankly admitted in the Newspeak word DUCKSPEAK, meaning 'to quack like a duck'.

name: ambivalent
trans: adj.矛盾的, 好恶相克的。
example: Like various other words in the B vocabulary, DUCKSPEAK was ambivalent in meaning.

name: Provided
trans: conj. 假如,如果
example: Provided that the opinions which were quacked out were orthodox ones, it implied nothing but praise, and when 'The Times' referred to one of the orators of the Party as a DOUBLEPLUSGOOD DUCKSPEAKER it was paying a warm and valued compliment.

name: DOUBLEPLUSGOOD
example: Provided that the opinions which were quacked out were orthodox ones, it implied nothing but praise, and when 'The Times' referred to one of the orators of the Party as a DOUBLEPLUSGOOD DUCKSPEAKER it was paying a warm and valued compliment.

name: DUCKSPEAKER
example: Provided that the opinions which were quacked out were orthodox ones, it implied nothing but praise, and when 'The Times' referred to one of the orators of the Party as a DOUBLEPLUSGOOD DUCKSPEAKER it was paying a warm and valued compliment.

name: paying
trans: adj.支付的，有利的n.付，支付v.付给（ pay的现在分词 ）,付款,有利可图,（对…）有利
example: Provided that the opinions which were quacked out were orthodox ones, it implied nothing but praise, and when 'The Times' referred to one of the orators of the Party as a DOUBLEPLUSGOOD DUCKSPEAKER it was paying a warm and valued compliment.

name: valued
trans: adj.宝贵的
example: Provided that the opinions which were quacked out were orthodox ones, it implied nothing but praise, and when 'The Times' referred to one of the orators of the Party as a DOUBLEPLUSGOOD DUCKSPEAKER it was paying a warm and valued compliment.

name: compliment
trans: n. 敬意,赞扬;问候;vt. 恭维;称赞
example: Provided that the opinions which were quacked out were orthodox ones, it implied nothing but praise, and when 'The Times' referred to one of the orators of the Party as a DOUBLEPLUSGOOD DUCKSPEAKER it was paying a warm and valued compliment.

name: VOCABULARY
trans: n. 词汇，词汇量；词汇表
example: THE C VOCABULARY.

name: supplementary
trans: adj.补充的,额外的
example: The C vocabulary was supplementary to the others and consisted entirely of scientific and technical terms.

name: define
trans: v. 给…下定义；阐述；阐释；限定，规定
example: These resembled the scientific terms in use today, and were constructed from the same roots, but the usual care was taken to define them rigidly and strip them of undesirable meanings.

name: vocabularies
example: They followed the same grammatical rules as the words in the other two vocabularies.

name: currency
trans: n.通货，货币
example: Very few of the C words had any currency either in everyday speech or in political speech.

name: smattering
trans: 少量
example: Any scientific worker or technician could find all the words he needed in the list devoted to his own speciality, but he seldom had more than a smattering of the words occurring in the other lists.

name: irrespective
trans: a. 不考虑的,不顾的
example: Only a very few words were common to all lists, and there was no vocabulary expressing the function of Science as a habit of mind, or a method of thought, irrespective of its particular branches.

name: bear
trans: n. 熊;粗鲁的人;v. 携带;有,怀有;承受,忍受;生育
example: There was, indeed, no word for 'Science', any meaning that it could possibly bear being already sufficiently covered by the word INGSOC.

name: foregoing
trans: adj.先行的，上述的
example: From the foregoing account it will be seen that in Newspeak the expression of unorthodox opinions, above a very low level, was well-nigh impossible.

name: nigh
trans: 近于
在附近的；直接的
几乎；在附近地
(Nigh)人名；(英)奈伊
example: From the foregoing account it will be seen that in Newspeak the expression of unorthodox opinions, above a very low level, was well-nigh impossible.

name: crude
trans: a. 天然的;粗鲁的;粗制的
example: It was of course possible to utter heresies of a very crude kind, a species of blasphemy.

name: species
trans: n. 生物的种;种类
example: It was of course possible to utter heresies of a very crude kind, a species of blasphemy.

name: blasphemy
trans: n.对上帝的亵渎，亵渎的言词行为,侮慢的言词（或行为）
example: It was of course possible to utter heresies of a very crude kind, a species of blasphemy.

name: UNGOOD
trans: a. 好的；善良的；擅长的；乖的n. 好处；利益
example: It would have been possible, for example, to say BIG BROTHER IS UNGOOD.

name: conveyed
trans: vt. 运送;转达,传达
example: But this statement, which to an orthodox ear merely conveyed a self-evident absurdity, could not have been sustained by reasoned argument, because the necessary words were not available.

name: sustained
trans: v. 维持（sustain的过去式和过去分词）；承受
adj. 持续的；持久的；持久不变的
example: But this statement, which to an orthodox ear merely conveyed a self-evident absurdity, could not have been sustained by reasoned argument, because the necessary words were not available.

name: reasoned
trans: adj.合乎逻辑的，经过周密思考的v.推理，思考( reason的过去式),争辩,推理，思考( reason的过去式和过去分词),争辩
example: But this statement, which to an orthodox ear merely conveyed a self-evident absurdity, could not have been sustained by reasoned argument, because the necessary words were not available.

name: Ideas
trans: abbr. 工业设计优秀奖
example: Ideas inimical to Ingsoc could only be entertained in a vague wordless form, and could only be named in very broad terms which lumped together and condemned whole groups of heresies without defining them in doing so.

name: entertained
trans: v. 招待，款待；使娱乐；使欢乐；容纳，接受
example: Ideas inimical to Ingsoc could only be entertained in a vague wordless form, and could only be named in very broad terms which lumped together and condemned whole groups of heresies without defining them in doing so.

name: lumped
trans: n. 团,块,肿块;vt. 合在一起,结块
example: Ideas inimical to Ingsoc could only be entertained in a vague wordless form, and could only be named in very broad terms which lumped together and condemned whole groups of heresies without defining them in doing so.

name: defining
trans: v.规定( define的现在分词 ),使明确,精确地解释,画出…的线条
example: Ideas inimical to Ingsoc could only be entertained in a vague wordless form, and could only be named in very broad terms which lumped together and condemned whole groups of heresies without defining them in doing so.

name: illegitimately
trans: n. 非嫡出子；庶子
adj. 私生的；非法的；不合理的
vt. 认做私生子；认为违法
example: One could, in fact, only use Newspeak for unorthodox purposes by illegitimately translating some of the words back into Oldspeak.

name: translating
trans: v. 翻译，解释；转化，
example: One could, in fact, only use Newspeak for unorthodox purposes by illegitimately translating some of the words back into Oldspeak.

name: ALL
trans: a. 全部的；非常的ad. 完全地，很pron. 全部
example: For example, ALL MANS ARE EQUAL was a possible Newspeak sentence, but only in the same sense in which ALL MEN ARE REDHAIRED is a possible Oldspeak sentence.

name: ARE
trans: 是（be的第二人称单复数现在式）
公亩
example: For example, ALL MANS ARE EQUAL was a possible Newspeak sentence, but only in the same sense in which ALL MEN ARE REDHAIRED is a possible Oldspeak sentence.

name: EQUAL
trans: a./n./vt. 相等的,相等于,相等匹敌
example: For example, ALL MANS ARE EQUAL was a possible Newspeak sentence, but only in the same sense in which ALL MEN ARE REDHAIRED is a possible Oldspeak sentence.

name: MEN
trans: n. 男人，人类（man的复数）
example: For example, ALL MANS ARE EQUAL was a possible Newspeak sentence, but only in the same sense in which ALL MEN ARE REDHAIRED is a possible Oldspeak sentence.

name: REDHAIRED
example: For example, ALL MANS ARE EQUAL was a possible Newspeak sentence, but only in the same sense in which ALL MEN ARE REDHAIRED is a possible Oldspeak sentence.

name: error
trans: n. 错误，过失
example: It did not contain a grammatical error, but it expressed a palpable untruth--i.

name: size
trans: n. 大小，尺寸，规模；尺码
example: that all men are of equal size, weight, or strength.

name: accordingly
trans: ad. 相应地，照着办，按照；于是，因此
example: The concept of political equality no longer existed, and this secondary meaning had accordingly been purged out of the word EQUAL.

name: theoretically
trans: adv.理论地，理论上
example: In 1984, when Oldspeak was still the normal means of communication, the danger theoretically existed that in using Newspeak words one might remember their original meanings.

name: grounded
trans: adj. 接(好)地的
example: In practice it was not difficult for any person well grounded in DOUBLETHINK to avoid doing this, but within a couple of generations even the possibility of such a lapse would have vanished.

name: attaching
trans: v. 系上,附上;依恋;认为
example: A person growing up with Newspeak as his sole language would no more know that EQUAL had once had the secondary meaning of 'politically equal', or that FREE had once meant 'intellectually free', than for instance, a person who had never heard of chess would be aware of the secondary meanings attaching to QUEEN and ROOK.

name: QUEEN
trans: n. 女王，皇后，王后
example: A person growing up with Newspeak as his sole language would no more know that EQUAL had once had the secondary meaning of 'politically equal', or that FREE had once meant 'intellectually free', than for instance, a person who had never heard of chess would be aware of the secondary meanings attaching to QUEEN and ROOK.

name: ROOK
example: A person growing up with Newspeak as his sole language would no more know that EQUAL had once had the secondary meaning of 'politically equal', or that FREE had once meant 'intellectually free', than for instance, a person who had never heard of chess would be aware of the secondary meanings attaching to QUEEN and ROOK.

name: nameless
trans: adj.无名的
example: There would be many crimes and errors which it would be beyond his power to commit, simply because they were nameless and therefore unimaginable.

name: characteristics
trans: 特点，特征
example: And it was to be foreseen that with the passage of time the distinguishing characteristics of Newspeak would become more and more pronounced--its words growing fewer and fewer, their meanings more and more rigid, and the chance of putting them to improper uses always diminishing.

name: rigid
trans: a. 僵硬的,不易弯的;严格的
example: And it was to be foreseen that with the passage of time the distinguishing characteristics of Newspeak would become more and more pronounced--its words growing fewer and fewer, their meanings more and more rigid, and the chance of putting them to improper uses always diminishing.

name: diminishing
trans: adj.逐渐缩小的v.（使）减少，缩小( diminish的现在分词 ),减弱…的权势
example: And it was to be foreseen that with the passage of time the distinguishing characteristics of Newspeak would become more and more pronounced--its words growing fewer and fewer, their meanings more and more rigid, and the chance of putting them to improper uses always diminishing.

name: link
trans: v. 连接，联系n. 环节，链环
example: When Oldspeak had been once and for all superseded, the last link with the past would have been severed.

name: censored
trans: adj.受审查的，被删剪的v.删剪（书籍、电影等中被认为犯忌、违反道德或政治上危险的内容）( censor的过去式和过去分词 )
example: History had already been rewritten, but fragments of the literature of the past survived here and there, imperfectly censored, and so long as one retained one's knowledge of Oldspeak it was possible to read them.

name: untranslatable
example: In the future such fragments, even if they chanced to survive, would be unintelligible and untranslatable.

name: translate
trans: v. 翻译，解释；转化，
example: It was impossible to translate any passage of Oldspeak into Newspeak unless it either referred to some technical process or some very simple everyday action, or was already orthodox (GOODTHINKFUL would be the Newspeak expression) in tendency.

name: approximately
trans: ad.近似地，大约
example: In practice this meant that no book written before approximately 1960 could be translated as a whole.

name: Pre
example: Pre-revolutionary literature could only be subjected to ideological translation--that is, alteration in sense as well as language.

name: Declaration
trans: n. 宣言，宣布，声明
example: Take for example the well-known passage from the Declaration of Independence: WE HOLD THESE TRUTHS TO BE SELF-EVIDENT, THAT ALL MEN ARE CREATED EQUAL, THAT THEY ARE ENDOWED BY THEIR CREATOR WITH CERTAIN INALIENABLE RIGHTS, THAT AMONG THESE ARE LIFE, LIBERTY, AND THE PURSUIT OF HAPPINESS.

name: render
trans: vt. 提供,报答;表演,演奏;翻译
example: It would have been quite impossible to render this into Newspeak while keeping to the sense of the original.

name: swallow
trans: vt. 吞,咽;轻信,轻易接受;承受,使不流露
example: The nearest one could come to doing so would be to swallow the whole passage up in the single word CRIMETHINK.

name: whereby
trans: ad. 凭什么,靠那个,借以
example: A full translation could only be an ideological translation, whereby Jefferson's words would be changed into a panegyric on absolute government.

name: Jefferson
example: A full translation could only be an ideological translation, whereby Jefferson's words would be changed into a panegyric on absolute government.

name: panegyric
trans: 赞颂之词，颂文
example: A full translation could only be an ideological translation, whereby Jefferson's words would be changed into a panegyric on absolute government.

name: transformed
trans: vt. 改变(形状性质等)
example: A good deal of the literature of the past was, indeed, already being transformed in this way.

name: Considerations
trans: n. 需要考虑的事，理由；考虑，思考；体谅，照顾
example: Considerations of prestige made it desirable to preserve the memory of certain historical figures, while at the same time bringing their achievements into line with the philosophy of Ingsoc.

name: prestige
trans: n. 威信,声望;(由于成功、财富等而产生)显赫
example: Considerations of prestige made it desirable to preserve the memory of certain historical figures, while at the same time bringing their achievements into line with the philosophy of Ingsoc.

name: Various

example: Various writers, such as Shakespeare, Milton, Swift, Byron, Dickens, and some others were therefore in process of translation: when the task had been completed, their original writings, with all else that survived of the literature of the past, would be destroyed.

name: translations

example: These translations were a slow and difficult business, and it was not expected that they would be finished before the first or second decade of the twenty-first century.

name: utilitarian
trans: 功利的；功利主义的；实利的
功利主义者
example: There were also large quantities of merely utilitarian literature--indispensable technical manuals, and the like--that had to be treated in the same way.

name: manuals
trans: a. 手工的,用手的;n. 手册;便览

name: adoption
trans: n.收养；采纳，采取

name: END
trans: n. 末端，端，梢；目标，目的v. 终止，结束
example: THE END
